entries.title: 2024 Tata Nexon Review: Still the Best Compact SUV?
entries.excerpt: The Tata Nexon continues to impress with its 5-star safety rating, peppy engines, and feature-rich cabin. Here's our comprehensive review.
entries.content:
The Tata Nexon has been a game-changer in the Indian compact SUV segment. With its bold design, 5-star Global NCAP safety rating, and feature-packed cabin, it continues to be a top choice for buyers.

The exterior design remains fresh with sharp LED DRLs, a bold front grille, and muscular body lines. The interior has received significant updates with a larger 10.25-inch touchscreen, ventilated seats, and premium materials throughout.

Under the hood, the 1.5-liter diesel engine produces 118 bhp and 260 Nm of torque, mated to a slick 6-speed manual. The engine is refined, offers excellent low-end torque, and returns impressive fuel efficiency of 21.5 km/l.

Ride quality is excellent, with the suspension soaking up bumps effectively. The steering is light and easy to maneuver in city traffic. Safety equipment is comprehensive with 6 airbags, ESP, and ISOFIX mounts.
cons: Rear seat space could be better
Boot space is average at 350 liters
Diesel engine can be noisy at high RPMs
entries.verdict: The Tata Nexon remains our top pick in the compact SUV segment. It offers the best combination of safety, features, and value for money. Highly recommended for families looking for a safe and stylish SUV.

entries.title: Hyundai Creta 2024 First Drive: Premium Redefined
entries.excerpt: The new Hyundai Creta raises the bar with segment-first features and a premium cabin. We take it for a spin.
entries.content:
Hyundai has updated the Creta with a fresh face and even more features. The new design is more aggressive with a parametric grille and connected LED DRLs.

Inside, the Creta impresses with dual 10.25-inch screens, a panoramic sunroof, and Bose premium audio. The BlueLink connected car tech offers 60+ features including remote start and geo-fencing.

The 1.5-liter turbo petrol with 7-speed DCT is our pick for its punchy performance and quick shifts. It delivers 160 bhp and 253 Nm, making highway overtakes effortless.

Ride quality is plush, and the cabin remains whisper-quiet at highway speeds. The ADAS suite adds a layer of safety with features like lane keep assist and adaptive cruise control.
cons: Turbo variant only available in top trims
Boot space reduced due to battery placement
entries.verdict: The Hyundai Creta continues to set benchmarks in the mid-size SUV segment. While expensive, it offers features that rivals simply cannot match.

entries.title: Maruti Swift 2024: The New Generation Hatchback King
entries.excerpt: The all-new Swift brings a fresh design, improved safety, and better fuel efficiency. Is it still India's favorite hatchback?
entries.content:
The fourth-generation Maruti Swift has arrived with a completely new design language. The sharp LED headlamps, floating roof design, and sporty stance give it a premium look.

The new Z-Series 1.2-liter petrol engine produces 82 bhp and offers segment-best fuel efficiency of 25 km/l. The engine is paired with either a 5-speed manual or AMT.

The cabin is a major upgrade with a 9-inch SmartPlay Pro+ touchscreen, wireless charging, and cruise control. Safety has improved with 6 airbags standard across all variants.

The Swift's light weight (880 kg) makes it nimble and fun to drive. The suspension handles our broken roads well, though rear seat comfort could be better.
entries.verdict: The new Swift is a worthy successor that addresses the safety concerns of the previous generation while retaining its fun-to-drive character.

entries.title: Mahindra XUV700 Long Term Review: 20,000 km Report
entries.excerpt: We've lived with the XUV700 for 20,000 km. Here's everything you need to know about owning Mahindra's flagship SUV.
entries.content:
After 20,000 km with the Mahindra XUV700, we can confidently say it's one of the best SUVs money can buy in India. The 2.2-liter diesel with 185 bhp and 420 Nm has been an absolute workhorse.

The ADAS features have proved useful on highway drives, with the adaptive cruise control being a standout. The lane keep assist took some getting used to but works well on well-marked roads.

Fuel efficiency has averaged 14 km/l in mixed driving, which is acceptable for a 2-tonne SUV. The 6-speed automatic has been smooth but occasionally hunts for gears on inclines.

Build quality has held up well with no rattles or squeaks developing. Service costs at Mahindra are reasonable, and spare parts availability has not been an issue.
cons: Third row is for kids only
entries.verdict: The XUV700 has proven to be a reliable companion over 20,000 km. It offers flagship features at a competitive price and is highly recommended for families.

entries.title: Honda City vs Hyundai Verna: Premium Sedan Showdown
entries.car_name: Honda City ZX CVT vs Hyundai Verna SX(O)
entries.excerpt: Two of India's best sedans go head-to-head. Which one deserves your money?
entries.content:
The Honda City and Hyundai Verna have been arch-rivals for over a decade. We compare the top variants of both to help you decide.

In terms of design, the Verna looks sportier with its swept-back profile, while the City has a more elegant, timeless appeal. Both have premium interiors with leather seats and dual-zone climate control.

The City's 1.5-liter petrol with CVT offers 121 bhp and is incredibly refined. The Verna's turbo petrol with DCT produces 160 bhp and is more exciting to drive.

Both sedans offer ADAS features in their top variants. The Verna has ventilated front seats, while the City offers LaneWatch camera - a unique feature in the segment.

In terms of value, the City offers better after-sales support and lower running costs, while the Verna offers more features per rupee.
pros: Honda City: Refined CVT, better resale value
Hyundai Verna: More powerful, more features
entries.verdict: Choose the City for reliability and refinement. Pick the Verna if you want more power and features. Both are excellent sedans.

entries.title: Kia Seltos 2024 Review: The Feature King Returns
entries.excerpt: The updated Kia Seltos packs even more features. We review the mid-spec HTX+ variant.
entries.content:
Kia has given the Seltos a comprehensive update for 2024. The front gets a new tiger-nose grille with LED DRLs that extend into the bonnet.

The star of the show is the 10.25-inch touchscreen with the updated UVO Connect system offering 70+ connected features. You also get a Bose premium audio system, ventilated seats, and an air purifier.

We tested the 1.5-liter turbo petrol with 160 bhp and 7-speed DCT. It's punchy off the line and the DCT shifts are quick. Fuel efficiency averaged 15 km/l in city driving.

Ride quality is excellent, with the suspension handling broken roads well. The steering is light and easy to use, making the Seltos a great city car.

Safety kit includes 6 airbags, ESC, and ADAS features like forward collision warning and lane keep assist.
cons: Some features reserved for top trim
entries.verdict: The Kia Seltos remains the feature king of the mid-size SUV segment. The HTX+ offers the best balance of features and value.

entries.title: Toyota Fortuner 2024: The Unstoppable SUV
entries.excerpt: The Toyota Fortuner continues to dominate the premium SUV segment. We test the 4x4 automatic variant.
entries.content:
The Toyota Fortuner needs no introduction. It's been the best-selling premium SUV in India for years, and the 2024 update adds more features while retaining its legendary reliability.

The 2.8-liter diesel produces 204 bhp and a massive 500 Nm of torque. Mated to a 6-speed automatic and 4WD system, it can tackle any terrain with ease.

We took the Fortuner on a 1000 km road trip including some off-road trails. The 4WD system with locking differential handled everything from sand to rocks without breaking a sweat.

Ride quality on tarmac is comfortable but can get bouncy at high speeds. The new 8-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay adds modern connectivity.

Safety features include 7 airbags, VSC, and a 360-degree camera. The build quality is typically Toyota - solid and rattle-free.
entries.verdict: The Fortuner is the SUV of choice if you need a rugged, reliable vehicle that can go anywhere. Premium pricing is justified by legendary reliability.

entries.title: MG Hector Plus: Best 6-Seater SUV for Families
entries.excerpt: The MG Hector Plus with captain seats offers a comfortable 6-seater configuration. Is it the best choice for large families?
entries.content:
The MG Hector Plus fills a unique gap in the market - a 6-seater SUV with captain chairs in the second row. For families needing comfortable seating for 6, it's an excellent choice.

The 14-inch touchscreen remains the largest in any car sold in India. The i-SMART 2.0 system offers 70+ connected features including Hinglish voice commands.

We tested the 1.5-liter turbo petrol with CVT. It produces 143 bhp and 250 Nm. Performance is adequate for city driving, though the CVT can feel sluggish during quick overtakes.

The captain chairs in the second row are supremely comfortable with individual armrests. Third-row access is easy thanks to tumble-down middle seats.

Boot space with all seats up is just 155 liters, which is a compromise for the 6-seat layout.
entries.verdict: The Hector Plus is perfect for families needing comfortable seating for 6 adults. The features on offer are unmatched in the segment.

entries.title: Skoda Slavia 1.5 TSI: Driver's Delight
entries.excerpt: The Skoda Slavia with the 1.5 TSI engine is the most fun-to-drive sedan in its class. Here's our verdict.
entries.content:
Skoda has finally given enthusiasts what they wanted - a proper driver's car in the mid-size sedan segment. The Slavia 1.5 TSI is that car.

The 1.5-liter TSI engine produces 150 bhp and 250 Nm. Paired with the 7-speed DSG, it rockets to 100 km/h in just 8.2 seconds. The power delivery is linear and the DSG shifts are quick.

The chassis is based on the MQB-A0-IN platform shared with the Kushaq. It offers excellent handling with minimal body roll. The steering is direct and confidence-inspiring.

Fuel efficiency is impressive at 18 km/l on the highway, thanks to cylinder deactivation technology. The interior is premium with quality materials and a 10-inch touchscreen.

Ride quality is on the stiffer side, which some may find uncomfortable on broken roads.
entries.verdict: The Slavia 1.5 TSI is the enthusiast's choice in the mid-size sedan segment. If you enjoy driving, look no further.

entries.title: Tata Punch EV: The Electric City Car
entries.car_name: Tata Punch EV Adventure Long Range
entries.excerpt: Tata's most affordable EV is here. The Punch EV promises fun city driving with zero emissions.
entries.content:
The Tata Punch EV is the newest addition to Tata's growing EV lineup. Based on the popular Punch, it offers a 35.5 kWh battery with a claimed range of 421 km.

In our real-world testing, we managed about 320 km on a full charge with AC on. That's still impressive for city commutes where most buyers won't drive more than 50 km daily.

The 122 bhp motor provides peppy performance. The instant torque makes traffic light getaways fun. There are multiple drive modes including Sport which maximizes performance.

The interior is similar to the regular Punch with a 10.25-inch touchscreen and connected car features. Regenerative braking is adjustable with four levels.

Charging takes about 45 minutes to 80% on a 50 kW DC fast charger. Home charging on a 15A socket takes about 10 hours for a full charge.
entries.verdict: The Punch EV is the perfect city car for those looking to go electric. The range is adequate for daily use and running costs are minimal.

entries.title: Mahindra Thar 2024: Adventure Unleashed
entries.excerpt: The Mahindra Thar is the most capable off-roader in India. We test its limits on the trails.
entries.content:
The Mahindra Thar is not just a vehicle; it's a lifestyle statement. The new generation Thar has retained its hardcore DNA while adding everyday usability.

We tested the 2.2-liter diesel with 130 bhp and 4WD. The low-range gearbox and locking differentials make it unstoppable off-road. Water wading capacity of 650mm means river crossings are no problem.

The hardtop variant offers better NVH and security. The touchscreen with navigation and Apple CarPlay adds modern connectivity. The adventure statistics display shows incline, altitude, and compass.

On-road manners have improved but it's still a body-on-frame SUV. Highway stability is acceptable, though crosswinds can be felt. The ride is stiff, especially on broken roads.

The rear bench in the 4-seat layout is usable only for short trips. Go for the 2-seat variant if you carry equipment regularly.
entries.verdict: The Thar is for those who crave adventure. It's not a practical family car, but for weekend warriors, it's unmatched.

entries.title: Hyundai i20 N Line: Hot Hatch for India
entries.excerpt: The i20 N Line brings sporty credentials to the premium hatchback segment. Is it worth the premium?
entries.content:
Hyundai's N Line series brings motorsport-inspired touches to regular models. The i20 N Line gets a 120 bhp turbo petrol with 7-speed DCT.

The exterior sports red accents, a sportier front bumper, and dual-tip exhausts. The all-black interior features N Line badging, red stitching, and sports seats.

Performance is lively with 0-100 km/h in 9.5 seconds. The DCT shifts are quick and there's a satisfying exhaust note when you push it. The stiffer suspension improves cornering but affects ride comfort.

The 10.25-inch touchscreen and digital cluster add a premium feel. BlueLink connectivity offers 60+ features including remote start.

At Rs 16 lakh, it's expensive for a hatchback. But if you want something that stands out and delivers driving thrills, it's worth considering.
entries.verdict: The i20 N Line is for those who want sporty styling without sacrificing practicality. It's not a true hot hatch, but it's the closest thing in India.

entries.title: Volkswagen Virtus GT: Sedan with Attitude
entries.excerpt: The Virtus GT shares its platform with the Slavia but adds VW's solid build quality. We put it to the test.
entries.content:
Volkswagen's Virtus is essentially a Slavia with VW badging and slightly different styling. The GT variant gets the punchy 1.5 TSI with 150 bhp.

The exterior is understated but elegant with chrome accents and LED everything. The interior is typical VW - solid, well-built, and no-nonsense.

The 1.5 TSI is the star of the show. It offers 0-100 km/h in 8.4 seconds and feels eager at any speed. The DSG is responsive and fuel efficiency is impressive at 17 km/l.

Handling is sharp with minimal body roll. The suspension is on the stiffer side, which enthusiasts will appreciate. Brakes are strong with great feedback.

The 10-inch touchscreen runs VW's latest software with wireless Apple CarPlay. Safety features include 6 airbags and ESC as standard.
entries.verdict: The Virtus GT is a well-rounded performance sedan. If you value driving dynamics and build quality over features, this is your pick.

entries.title: Tata Safari 2024: 7-Seater Done Right
entries.excerpt: The Tata Safari offers 3-row seating with genuine comfort. We test the Adventure Edition.
entries.content:
The Tata Safari has evolved from a rugged SUV to a premium family mover. The 2024 Adventure Edition adds unique styling touches and equipment.

The exterior gets rugged black cladding, roof rails, and adventure badges. The interior features a black and white theme with leather upholstery.

The 2.0-liter diesel produces 170 bhp and 350 Nm. Performance is adequate but the 1.9-tonne weight is felt during quick acceleration. The 6-speed automatic shifts smoothly.

The second row is the highlight with captain chairs and boss mode for max legroom. Third-row access is easy and adults can sit there for short distances.

Safety is comprehensive with 6 airbags, ESP, and ADAS features like forward collision warning.
entries.verdict: The Safari is a comfortable family SUV with genuine 7-seat capability. The Adventure Edition adds visual appeal without compromising practicality.

entries.title: Maruti Grand Vitara Hybrid: Most Fuel-Efficient SUV
entries.excerpt: The Grand Vitara Hybrid delivers an incredible 27.9 km/l. We test its real-world efficiency.
entries.content:
The Maruti Grand Vitara with Toyota's hybrid tech is the most fuel-efficient SUV in India. We put its efficiency claims to the test.

The self-charging hybrid combines a 1.5-liter petrol with an electric motor for a combined 116 bhp. It can run on electric-only at low speeds, switching seamlessly to petrol when needed.

In our testing, we achieved 25.5 km/l in city driving - remarkable for a 4.3-meter SUV. Highway efficiency dropped to 22 km/l due to higher speeds.

The e-CVT is smooth but acceleration feels leisurely. The hybrid system prioritizes efficiency over performance, which is fine for its target audience.

The cabin is premium with a 9-inch touchscreen, connected car tech, and wireless charging. Safety includes 6 airbags and hill assist.
entries.verdict: The Grand Vitara Hybrid is perfect for those who want an SUV with sedan-like running costs. It's the smart choice for high-mileage users.

entries.title: Jeep Meridian: Premium 7-Seater SUV
entries.excerpt: The Jeep Meridian offers American SUV appeal with 7 seats. Is it worth the premium asking price?
entries.content:
The Jeep Meridian is a 3-row version of the Compass. It stretches the platform to add a third row while retaining Jeep's off-road credentials.

The exterior is unmistakably Jeep with the 7-slot grille and muscular fenders. The interior is premium with leather seats, a 10.1-inch touchscreen, and a digital cluster.

The 2.0-liter diesel produces 170 bhp and 350 Nm. The 9-speed automatic is smooth in normal driving but can hunt on inclines. 4x4 is available with Jeep's excellent terrain management system.

The second row offers good space with captain chairs. The third row is usable for adults on short trips, better than most rivals.

At Rs 35 lakh onwards, it's expensive. But for those who want a capable off-roader with 7 seats, options are limited.
entries.verdict: The Meridian is for those who want an authentic SUV experience with 7 seats. It's expensive but offers what rivals cannot - genuine off-road capability.

entries.title: Citroen C3 Aircross: Value Champion
entries.excerpt: The C3 Aircross offers genuine 7-seat capability at an unbeatable price. We test its real-world usability.
entries.content:
Citroen has positioned the C3 Aircross as the most affordable 7-seater in India. At under Rs 12 lakh, it undercuts rivals by a significant margin.

The exterior is quirky with split headlamps and rugged body cladding. The cabin is simple but functional with a 10-inch touchscreen as the centerpiece.

The 1.2-liter turbo produces 110 bhp and feels adequate for city driving. The 6-speed manual gearbox has a light throw. A 6-speed torque converter automatic is also available.

The third row is usable for kids and offers 50:50 split folding. Boot space with all seats up is just 100 liters, so you'll need to fold seats for luggage.

At this price, compromises are expected. No wireless phone charging, no automatic climate control, and no sunroof. But the basics are done well.
entries.verdict: The C3 Aircross is the value champion. If budget is a priority and you need 7 seats, nothing comes close.

entries.title: BYD Atto 3: The Electric Revolution
entries.excerpt: BYD's Atto 3 brings Chinese EV excellence to India. We test its claims of 521 km range.
entries.content:
BYD, the world's largest EV manufacturer, has entered India with the Atto 3. It's a premium electric SUV with a 60.5 kWh Blade battery promising 521 km range.

In our testing, we achieved about 420 km of real-world range with AC on. That's still impressive and enough for most use cases.

The 201 bhp motor provides strong acceleration with 0-100 km/h in 7.3 seconds. The instant torque makes city driving effortless. Regenerative braking is adjustable.

The interior is unique with a rotating touchscreen that can switch between portrait and landscape. The panoramic glass roof adds to the airy feel.

BYD's Blade battery technology is impressive with 8-year warranty. Fast charging takes 29 minutes from 30-80%.
entries.verdict: The Atto 3 is a capable EV that offers more range than any sub-Rs 40 lakh electric car. Early adopters will find it rewarding.

entries.title: Renault Kiger Turbo: Budget Performance
entries.excerpt: The Renault Kiger offers turbo performance at hatchback prices. We test the CVT variant.
entries.content:
The Renault Kiger fills an interesting niche - a sub-4-meter SUV with turbo power at an accessible price point. The top RXZ Turbo CVT costs under Rs 11 lakh.

The 1.0-liter turbo produces 100 bhp and 160 Nm - more than enough to make the light Kiger feel quick. The CVT with stepped ratios offers reasonable engagement.

The exterior is polarizing with its split headlamp design. The interior is budget-focused but the 8-inch touchscreen with wireless Apple CarPlay adds value.

Ride quality is decent though the suspension can feel unsettled over sharp bumps. The steering is light and easy, making city driving stress-free.

Safety has improved with 4 airbags and ESC as standard. This addresses earlier concerns about the Kiger's safety credentials.
entries.verdict: The Kiger Turbo CVT offers good value for those wanting turbo performance on a budget. It's not refined, but it's honest.
